 Hate speech

 Nudity in profile pictures
 Defamation to a person or people
 Name calling and/or personal attacks
 Comments whose main purpose are to sell a product
 Comments that infringe on copyrights
 Spam comments, such as the same comment posted repeatedly on a profile
 Other comments that the RCAS deems inappropriate.

Congratulations to SHS student Jonathan Coronado on being named a 2020 Presidential Scholar!

Coronado is one of 161 outstanding American high school seniors who have demonstrated outstanding academic achievement, artistic excellence, technical expertise, leadership, citizenship, service, and contribution to school and community.

The 2020 U.S. Presidential Scholars are comprised of one young man and one young woman from each state, the District of Columbia and Puerto Rico, and from U.S. families living abroad, as well as 15 chosen at-large, 20 U.S. Presidential Scholars in the Arts, and 20 U.S. Presidential Scholars in Career and Technical Education.

Since 1983, each U.S. Presidential Scholar has been offered the opportunity to name his or her most influential teacher. Each distinguished teacher is honored with a personal letter from the Secretary of Education. The teacher chosen for recognition by Coronado was Dr. Aliea Hernberg of Stevens High School.

COVID-19 Meal Service Update from Nutrition Services:

We want to give a BIG shout out to not only our nutrition services staff, but also transportation and custodial staff that have helped us feed kids during this difficult time. It has not been easy and we're "building the plane as we fly it" as some might say!

We are currently providing meal packets to 635 children each day which seems to be the sweet spot as we aren't running out of food, we have minimal leftovers, and we are able to maintain social distancing in the kitchens and while distributing. That's a total of 5,715 meals a week.

We have developed a "no-contact" system at our distribution sites where people pull up in their cars, open their trunks, we put the food in the trunk and step away, and they close their trunks and leave. Thank you for your cooperation in this process.

We have heard a ton of positive feedback and people seem to be very grateful for our meals during what's a trying time for many. Thank you again to all that have made this happen!!

**We will be serving meals tomorrow (4/8) and April 13th**

Dear Families,

You have likely already heard that Governor Noem wants schools to remain closed the rest of the school year. While I am not surprised by this news, I am certainly saddened by it. Along with the closure of schools, the South Dakota High School Activities Association has likewise cancelled all athletics and activities the rest of the school year.

We will continue with our distance learning the remainder of the school year. As such, we will also continue to monitor and adjust these plans as needed. The last day of school is May 28th. We will share more about how to get personal items from the building in the future.

I am already in communication with the Civic Center to find an alternative date for graduation later in the summer. I hope to share more soon.

For all of the latest updates and information related to the COVID-19 pandemic and its impact on our schools, please check out the District’s COVID-19 Information Hub at rcas.org.

I wish you and your families a peaceful spring break.

Sincerely,

Dr. Lori J. Simon
Superintendent

In an effort to understand the results (56.29% YES and 43.71% NO) of the recent bond election, which could have addressed the many facilities related needs in our district, adminstrators and the Board of Education want to hear from you. As many of you know, two years ago, the District convened a Task Force made up of parents, community members, and staff to study the District’s facility needs and propose a plan to address them. That proposal, with a few tweaks, was what voters voted on last month. While the majority of voters did support the plan, a super majority of 60 percent + 1 is needed to pass a bond. In light of this, we need to know why some chose to support this plan and why others did not. Your feedback will help determine the District’s next steps. If you have additional feedback that you would like to share, please reach out to Katy Urban at ‪(605)394-4091‬ or via email at Katy.urban@k12.sd.us.

Your voice matters, our kids matter!

Here is the link to the short survey.
https://www.surveymonkey.com/r/7KWYPSM

Individuals advancing to the state competition are: Gunner Edson (8th Grade) from Georgia Morse Middle School in Pierre, Gabe Reeve (7th Grade) and Aron Csornok (8th Grade) from South Middle School, and Thurston Diaz (7th Grade) from West Middle School, in Rapid City.

Information about their child’s development is shared with parents, and parents will be provided with ideas to help enhance their children’s development.
